section.heading: Scope.
section.text: This chapter establishes standards for use as a guide for the imposition of disciplinary sanctions against any Maryland licensed podiatrist, if after a hearing the Board finds that there are grounds under Health Occupations Article, §16-311, Annotated Code of Maryland, to place a licensee on probation, reprimand, suspend, fine, or revoke a license. The Board may consider aggravating and mitigating factors in determining sanctions.

para.text: In this chapter, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.
“Board” means the Board of Podiatric Medical Examiners.
“Licensee” means an individual who holds a license or a limited license to practice podiatry in Maryland.
This chapter shall be used by the Board as a guide for sanctioning licensees.
The Board is not required to make findings of fact with respect to any of the factors for determining the sanction indicated by the sanctioning guidelines.
A departure from the sanctioning guidelines alone is not a ground for any hearing or appeal of a Board action.

Notwithstanding this chapter, in order to resolve a disciplinary matter, the Board and the licensee may agree to a surrender of license or a consent order with terms, conditions, and sanctions agreed to by the Board and the licensee.
In a case where there are multiple and distinct violations, the Board may impose a sanction greater than the maximum indicated in Regulation .04 of this chapter for each individual violation.

If probation is imposed, the Board may impose appropriate terms and conditions of probation, and if a licensee violates the terms or conditions of probation, the Board may take further disciplinary action against the licensee.

In the event the licensee’s violation does not fall within the sanction range, the Board shall so indicate and use its best judgment to determine the appropriate sanction and shall consider, to the extent possible, the factors in Regulation .05 of this chapter.

section.heading: Mitigating and Aggravating Factors.
section.text: Depending upon the facts and circumstances of each case, and to the extent that they apply, the Board may consider the following mitigating and aggravating factors in determining whether the sanction in a particular case should fall outside of the range of sanctions established by the guidelines. These factors may include, but are not limited, to the following:

para.text: Mitigating factors:
Absence of a prior disciplinary record;
The licensee having reported the violation to the Board;
The licensee having voluntarily admitted violation, provided full disclosure to the Board, and cooperated during Board proceedings;
The licensee having implemented remedial measures to correct or mitigate harm arising from the violation;
The licensee having made a timely good-faith effort to make restitution or otherwise rectify the consequences of the violation;
Evidence of rehabilitation or potential for rehabilitation;
Absence of premeditation to commit the violation;
Absence of potential harm to or adverse impact on the public;
Isolated incident and not likely to recur; and
The licensee’s prior community service and present value to the community; and
Aggravating factors:
Previous criminal or administrative disciplinary history;
The violation was committed deliberately or with gross negligence or recklessness;
The violation had the potential for, or caused, serious patient harm;
The violation was part of a pattern of detrimental conduct;
The licensee was motivated to perform the violation by his or her financial gain;
The vulnerability of the patient;
The licensee attempted to conceal the violation, falsified or destroyed evidence, or presented false testimony or evidence;
The licensee failed to cooperate with the Board’s investigation; and
Previous attempts at rehabilitation were unsuccessful.
